titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Cadell & Davies Records
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 06:35

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Correspondence, promissory notes, receipts, and statements of account documenting the publishing and bookselling business of Cadell & Davies. The records include letters from contemporary authors and printers, as well as substantial correspondence with the poet and novelist Charlotte Turner Smith. Other correspondents include Edward Daniel Clarke, George Huntingford, William Magee, Edward Maltby, Isaac Milner, Charles Simeon, and Nathaniel Wraxall.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Library Associates (purchased from Stonehill), 1939.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Cadell & Davies Records are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Cadell & Davies Records. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was produced from a previously existing card set in the Manuscripts Catalog, or from another inventory. All pertinent bibliographical information has been retained. If the collection also contains unlisted or unsorted material, this has been noted in the box-and-folder list.

bioghist.head: CADELL & DAVIES
bioghist.p: The British publishing and bookselling firm of Cadell & Davies was established in 1793 when Thomas Cadell the elder (1742-1802) retired from the publishing world, bequeathing his business to his apprentice, William Davies (d. 1820), and his son, Thomas Cadell (1773-1836). The new partners located their firm on the Strand in London, with Davies managing most of the partnership's affairs until he became ill in 1813. Cadell consequently became more involved with the firm's business, establishing himself and the publishing house as major players in the London book trade. After Davies's death in 1820, Cadell began publishing under his own name.
The firm was dissolved in 1836 when Thomas Cadell died, although several years passed before the Cadell imprint disappeared. Remaining stocks and copyrights were sold in 1840.

For additional information, see The Publishing Firm of Cadell & Davies: Select Correspondence and Accounts, 1793-1836, edited with an introduction and notes by Theodore Besterman (London: Oxford Univ. Press, 1938).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
The Cadell & Davies Records consist primarily of correspondence, receipts, bank notes and legal agreements relating to the publishing and bookselling business of Cadell & Davies. The records are organized into one series, Series I. Business Files
, and are alphabetically arranged by correspondent. The papers span the dates 1767 to 1831 though the bulk of the material falls in the period 1790 to 1820.

Incoming correspondence from authors and prospective book purchasers, some annotated by the publishers, is interfiled with copies of replies written by Thomas Cadell and William Davies. The records also include a few letters addressed to the elder Thomas Cadell, as well as notes from printers such as Richard Watts and Luke Hansard. These letters have been interfiled chronologically within the correspondence files.

The correspondence typically concerns negotiations between the author and Cadell & Davies. The letters offer insight into the complex network of relations among printer, engraver, publisher, and author; the roles that subscribers and patrons played in supporting the printing of specific works; the impact that advertising and literary reviews were believed to have on sales; and the difficulties of contemporary transport. The records also detail financial transactions, printing expenses, and the firm's contractual arrangements with authors and other booksellers.

The largest single correspondence is that between Charlotte Turner Smith and Cadell & Davies, which numbers over 130 letters, and provides an ongoing account of the circumstances prompting her literary career. In a letter dated October 20, 1797, she wrote that she was "too acutely sensible of the misery, the humiliation of being compelled, with so handsome a fortune of my own, and such claims on behalf of my children to be dependent on my writing... doomed from year to year to invent fable for the public & to take as a favor any price offered." The correspondence also includes Charlotte Smith's opinions of her worth as a writer, details about her family life and writing process, and information about the publication of Elegiac Sonnets (1789-1800), Rural Walks (1795), and Rambles Farther (1800).

The records also contain a significant amount of correspondence between Cadell & Davies and the travel writer Edward Daniel Clarke, primarily regarding the publication of his Travels (1810-1824) and ongoing contractual disputes. The historian Nathaniel Wraxhall's letters offer heated commentary on the Napoleonic Wars (1800-1815). Other correspondents with substantial material include George Huntingford, William Magee, Edward Maltby, Isaac Milner, and Charles Simeon.

Wrappers that previously enclosed the records have been placed at the end of the series in two folders. These wrappers include earlier cataloging information and occasionally provide biographical notes about correspondents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, Business Files , is arranged alphabetically by correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains 3 ALS to Cadell and Davies and copies of 2 ALS to John Adolphus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 23 receipts, notes, etc. drawn between John Adolphus and Cadell and Davies.

did.unittitle: Autograph note concerning publication of the works of John Adolphus
Autograph receipt, signed, issued to Cadell and Davies, London, April 20, 1801, and two promissory notes payable to him, with his endorsement
12 ALS to Cadell and Davies, London
Autograph copy, signed, of the title page of Travels in China , with chapter headings
Financial accounts of Africa and China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains 9 ALS to Cadell and Davies, Bath; ALS from Stuart Cheyne to Cadell and Davies regarding publication of Bowdler's Sermons , dated 1803 Apr 19; ALS from [J?] Smith to Cadell and Davies, dated 1807 Nov 27.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes ALS from J. Clarke to Mr. Davies, Petworth, dated Sep 5 and ALS from R. Watts, printer, to Cadell and Davies, Cambridge, dated Aug 10.

did.unittitle: 6 statements of accounts, promissory notes, receipts, etc.
15 promissory notes and receipts drawn between William Coxe and Cadell and Davies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes 3 ALS from J. Burkitt to Cadell and Davies regarding the printing of Nathan Drake's works, Suffolk.

did.unittitle: 4 promissory notes drawn between Nathan Drake and Cadell and Davies
Statement of account between Nathan Drake and Cadell and Davies
Memorandum of an agreement drawn between John Gifford and Henry Redhead York on the one part and the Messrs. Thomas Cadell and William Davies on the other part, London
Regarding the publication of Life of William Pitt .
7 promissory notes and drafts drawn between William Gilpin and Cadell and Davies, London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes anonymous AL to Thomas Gisborne, Birmingham, dated 1797 Dec 18.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes: ALS to Cadell and Davies from Henry Huntingford regarding publication of works by his uncle, George Huntingford, Winchester, dated 1806 Feb 18; 2 ALS regarding proof sheets of Bishop Huntingford's work. One is signed "Saml. Collingwood" and the other "L[uke] H[ansard]"; ALS from J. Burdon to Cadell and Davies regarding the printing of George Huntingford's works, Winchester, dated 1800 Jan 22.

did.unittitle: Autograph list of works of George Huntingford published by Cadell and Davies
2 ALS to Cadell and Davies, Bath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: First letter cut in two, part missing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes ALS to R. Watts from Cadell and Davies, dated 1829 Feb 23.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 3 ALS from R. Watts, printer, enclosed with letter from Cadell and Davies, dated 1829 Apr 2.

did.unittitle: Memorandum for an agreement between Dean Milner and Cadell and Davies, London
2 ALS to Cadell and Davies, London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes newspaper clipping advertising one of his works.

did.unittitle: 4 receipts to Cadell and Davies, London
Promissory note to Mrs. Mary Wilson, Fulham

scopecontent.p: Includes 2 notes written in the the third person, one possibly by Mr. Parkyn; ALS from Sir Lionel Smith, son of CS; and ALS from Lucy Smith, daughter of CS.
